Welcome to the frame I'm Steven quibble sitting in for John horn disappearance and presumed assassinations Saudi dissident journalist ... allegedly under the direction of Saudi crown prince Mohammed bin Salman continues to fuel outrage across the globe
And also poses an ethical dilemma for arts institutions with ties to the Saudi Government a year long cross cultural program called the New York Arab art in education initiative
Was launched earlier this month partly with the aid money from a nonprofit founded by the Saudi crown prince now some of the New York institutions involved in the initiative are either declining Saudi dollars are postponing related events Robin Pogrebin is covering the story for the New York times after the first explain what's behind the Arab art in education initiative
Was an effort to had to get to know the Arab world through culture whether it was exhibits panel discussions kind of impose yeah and so
There were several major American museums that agreed to participate and everyone was very excited about the prospect and you know while they had different manifestations of this project kale
Kind of bought into the idea of it and we're making plans right around now to move forward when obviously this became a serious ranch in the works
And what are some examples of the programming and exhibits there are a part of a year long initiative
Well for example um October twelve the Brooklyn Museum opened an exhibition of art and artifacts from Syria um the Guggenheim hosted a conversation with a Palestinian artist and the Metropolitan Museum of planning to hold a seminar on how museum's curator art from the middle east ...
So how's the international outrage over ... ... disappearance and apparent murder likely to alter the tone and the tenor of this art in education effort
I think that cultural institutions around the country as frankly it our political organizations are doing are are grappling with this issue of of how to balance this interest in what seemed very kind of positive effort to um
Established connections with the Saudi Government the Arab world more generally has now been very much complicated and potentially compromised by
What seems to be increasingly clear evidence that the Saudi Government
Played a role in cars show gates death and so now I think museums were
A Lowe's to immediately I'm kinda disavow al ... potentially cancel these events and activities that now they are having to think much more seriously and deeply about whether an ongoing um collaboration makes sense
Could it be that that the entire initiative is at risk or or just X amount of dollars of fun you know funding coming from the Saudis
I think definitely the entire enterprise is at risk as it is this
Was kind of a nascent relationship that was developing between these cultural institutions and the Saudi world and so it was definitely new territory and frankly the you know potential upside of having an infusion of dollars it's no small part of it these are cultural institutions that are struggling
Around the country um there's always this question of
A finite number of philanthropic dollars to compete for as well as diminishing government support and this was a really
Kind of a potentially great new pot to draw from and potentially benefit from that they now have to swear off and you know and it's very realistic that this is not going to be an option anymore and I think that's frustrating and they've been a little slow to
Us how to reconcile themselves to that what
Exactly is behind the Saudi government's interest in us art and culture
I mean I think it you know certainly there is the the image aspect of it I mean you know there are a lot of people who try to burnish um they're sort of a public relations
A profile with culture it's it seems to usually be a pretty benign um avenue
Of of collaboration I mean certainly for example um in cutter you know we've actually had the New York times art conference there a couple of times and the shake a has been a huge supporter of the arts and she put a lot of effort behind museums

And so um it's it's definitely something they're going to have to answer for it and that's what they're finding 'em in the case if this Saturday government

Is the ... really likely to permanently sever these ties and the art world
I think it really depends on how it plays out and I wouldn't say that they have kind of taken Saudi money and an uncomplicated away in the past they actually I think have sort of tiptoe around it they
Played it down they sometimes you know keep it at arm's distance I mean there is this ... foundation through which they Saudi money comes and so in a way this kind of ... art Institute it's sort of under the rubric of that that you see these collaborations happening
So you don't necessarily see how
Directs the relationship is um and there is kind of some effort to even obscure it but I think what happens when an event like this comes just for is you know suddenly it's all really laid bare and the connections become clear you have journalists like us kind of digging and making sure that the public is aware of them
